awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: 3D Printed High Performance Li-ion Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of three-dimensional (3D) printed battery electrodes that improve energy capacity and power performance. As batteries become an integral part of many products, from electronics to electric vehicles, the demand for high performance batteries is expected to grow considerably. The proposed technology may lead to advanced manufacturing techniques for Li-ion batteries that are well suited for consumer and wearable electronics – fields that are growing rapidly. Longer lasting high-performance batteries may help reduce e-waste by increasing device life. Supply of low-cost energy storage options also may lead to equitable access to energy that is critical for the use of technology. Additionally, these batteries potentially may be utilized in electric vehicles, which is a high growth industry attracting significant investment. Enabling the growth of electric vehicles through high performance batteries may have a significant impact on reducing carbon emissions. This innovation may shift the approach to battery development from materials discovery to process and manufacturing.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of ultra-thick electrodes (UTEs) using advanced aerosol jet (AJ) three-dimensional (3D) printing technology. Increasing electrode thickness reduces non-active components (e.g., current collectors, separator, etc.), resulting in large gains in energy density and a significant cost reduction. Increasing electrode thickness, however, delays the Lithium transport, causing poor power performance and capacity loss. Using 3D printing allows creation of UTEs without a loss of performance. UTEs created using the proposed process have been used to demonstrate improved charge times (7.5 minutes for 80% state-of-charge) and increased energy density (up 50% to 450 Wh/kg), by taking full advantage of the energy storage capability of the active materials.  In addition, preliminary results using the AJ printed battery show improved performance compared to conventional laminated structure. The silver-based 3D structured electrodes showed a 400% increase in specific capacity, 100% increase in areal capacity, and a high electrode volume utilization compared to a thin, solid silver block electrode. The proposed commercialization of this technology may advance battery development and change how batteries are manufactured.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF National I-Corps project focused on the development and commercialization potential of 3D printed batteries. These batteries improve energy density by enabling better utilization of the battery material, and improved cycling for longer battery performance. The primary objective was to validate hypotheses about market needs, customer segments, and product specifications that would accelerate adoption of this revolutionary battery technology.

Over 250 customers and individuals in the battery ecosystem were interviewed to understand the validity of the technology. The initial hypothesis was that wearable electronics would be the target beachhead market due for small, energy dense batteries. However, the wearable electronics market places higher value on the form factor and integration capabilities of batteries rather than just weight. This indicates a preference for innovative battery designs that fit seamlessly into wearable devices. The value proposition of the technology is actually best aligned with the drone market, which has a need for higher energy density batteries that enables longer flight times, expanding the market size for drone use cases. Ultimately, different markets value different performance specifications, and therefore require different battery types and designs.

Initially, it was assumed that most segments would value energy density the most. After interviewing customers in automotive, electronics, drones, wearable electronics, including AR/VR, and medical electronics, it was clear priorities varied widely. Although different segments have varying needs, common requirements include high energy density, long cycle life, and adaptability to various form factors. Safety is a critical factor across all the markets, and is viewed as a base requirement before considering a switch in technology. This emphasizes the need for customizable and versatile battery designs. 

When it comes to design and selecting battery technologies, engineers collaborate closely with product teams to determine battery needs. There is value in engaging both engineering and product management teams in the early stages of product development when developing a new battery. Product specifications often drive the selection of battery technology. While many companies have internal battery experts, many rely heavily on external suppliers for battery solutions. A key part of this process is internal testing and validation of the technology, which requires the manufacturer to send samples to the customer. This step is critical for the adaption of new battery technology.

The project demonstrated significant intellectual merit by advancing the understanding of how 3D printing technology can be applied to battery manufacturing. Key contributions include:

  • Innovative Manufacturing Techniques: Development of novel 3D printing methods for creating complex battery geometries that are not possible with traditional manufacturing.
  • Energy Storage Advancements: Exploration of new materials and composites for improved battery performance, including enhanced energy density and cycle life.
  • Customizable Solutions: Ability to tailor battery designs to specific application needs, offering a competitive advantage in markets requiring unique form factors.

The broader impacts of the project extend across multiple dimensions:

  • Economic Impact: By reducing the reliance on traditional battery supply chains and enabling localized manufacturing, the project has the potential to create new business opportunities and jobs in the emerging 3D printing sector.
  • Environmental Benefits: 3D printed batteries can reduce material waste and energy consumption during manufacturing, contributing to more sustainable production practices.
  • Enhanced Product Innovation: The ability to quickly prototype and iterate on battery designs can accelerate innovation across industries such as consumer electronics, automotive, and aerospace.
  • Educational Contributions: The project has provided valuable learning opportunities for students and researchers, fostering the next generation of innovators in additive manufacturing and energy storage technologies.

The NSF I-Corps project on 3D printed batteries successfully validated key market hypotheses and demonstrated both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the technology. The findings underscore the potential of 3D printed batteries to revolutionize energy storage solutions by offering customizable and high performance alternatives to traditional batteries. Continued research and development and further product development of this technology can result in commercial applications that address the critical shortcomings of today’s batteries.

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2025
Modified by: Rahul Panat
